    EGF-Containing Membrane-Bound Mucins: A Hidden ErbB2 Targeting Pathway?

    • Maxime Liberelle
      Maxime Liberelle
      Univ. Lille, Inserm CHU Lille, UMR-S1172-JPArc-Centre de Recherche Jean-Pierre Aubert Neurosciences et Cancer, F-59000 Lille, France

    SUBJECTS:
    • Targeting,

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Membrane-bound mucins belong to a heterogeneous family of large O-glycoproteins involved in numerous cancers and inflammatory diseases of the epithelium. Some of them are also involved in protein–protein interactions, with receptor tyrosine kinase ErbB2, and fundamental and clinical data showed that these complexes have a detrimental impact on cancer outcome, thus raising interest in therapeutic targeting. This paper aims to demonstrate that MUC3, MUC4, MUC12, MUC13, and MUC17 have a common evolutionary origin and share a common structural organization with EGF-like and SEA domains. Theoretical structure–function relationship analysis of the conserved domains indicated that the studied membrane-bound mucins share common biological properties along with potential specific functions. Finally, the potential druggability of these complexes is discussed, revealing ErbB2-related pathways of cell signaling to be targeted.

    I. Context

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Mucins form a family of large gel-forming O-glycoproteins synthesized by epithelial cells.(1) Arising from heterogeneous evolutionary origins,(2) they are organized into a peptidic chain called apomucin and a heavily glycosylated serine/threonine rich region. In addition to this O-glycosylation, which represents up to 50–80% of the total molecular weight of the molecule, N-glycosylation occurs to a lesser extent.(3) Mucins play a role in lubrication, transduction of the signal, cell–cell or cell–extracellular matrix communication, and barrier formations because of their abilities to filter compounds and ions and retain factors and water molecules.(4) Twenty-two mucin genes that encode two subfamilies of mucins have been described:(5) membrane-bound and secretory mucins. Herein, we focus on the membrane-bound mucins or transmembrane (TM) mucins that are typically localized at the apical surface of normal epithelial cells.(6) This subfamily includes MUC1, MUC3A/3B, MUC4, MUC12, MUC13, MUC15–MUC17, and MUC20–MUC22. They share common structural features. The N-terminal (Nt) part of the apomucin is composed of amino acid (aa) tandem repeats or pseudorepeated aa sequences, rich in serine and threonine residues, that are extensively glycosylated followed by a less glycosylated part of variable length. This extracellular part of the TM mucin may contain one or several structural and functional domains. This Nt part is noncovalently associated with the C-terminal (Ct) part that is composed of a single transmembrane helix followed by a cytoplasmic tail of approximately 70–80 residues, shorter for MUC4 (23 amino acids) and MUC16 (35 amino acids). While MUC15 and MUC20–MUC22 are almost exclusively composed of the O-glycosylated part directly followed by the transmembrane domain, the other TM mucins contain either epidermal growth factor (EGF)-like domains (MUC4) or a sperm protein, enterokinase and agrin (SEA) domain (MUC1 and MUC16), or both (MUC3A/3B, MUC12, MUC13, and MUC17). All mucins are post-transcriptionally cleaved at a site in the SEA domain, except for MUC4, which is cleaved at the consensus GDPH sequence.(7) MUC4 also contains several unique domains not found in other mucins (AMOP, NIDO, and VWD)(8,9) (Figure 1).
    This review will focus on MUC3, MUC4, MUC12, MUC13, and MUC17 TM mucins. Herein, we will thus focus on the mucins containing EGF domains and discuss their evolution, their structure, and their function. Other TM mucins will not be discussed for the following reasons. MUC1, which is evolutionary related with soluble mucins,(10) interacts with the EGFR pathway via its cytoplasmic tail and does not have an EGF domain. MUC16, which has a unique structure with its SEA repeat domains,(2) appears to come from distinct ancestors. MUC15 and MUC20–MUC22 do not have an extended apomucin part. Most of the reviews describing TM mucins are essentially focusing on their O-glycan part, on cleavage function, on the regulation of their expression at the genomic level, or on their role associated with resistance to apoptosis and resistance to chemotherapy.(8,11,12)
    Apart from their structure, TM mucins have common implications in pathological disorders, at the edge between inflammation and cancer,(7) and recently, some of them have attracted interest as potential and promising therapeutic targets.(13−15) We will discuss the links between their structures and biological properties, leading to a hypothesis about a new ErbB pathway to study and to target in therapeutic approaches. The EGFR/ErbB receptor family consists of a type I transmembrane growth factor receptor that comprised EGFR/HER/ErbB1, HER2/ErbB2 (derived from erythroblastic leukemia viral oncogene), HER3/ErbB3, and HER4/ErbB4.(16)
    In this work, we want to establish a new paradigm where EGF-like domain-containing TM mucins may be regarded as sharing common structural properties producing similar biological functions. This postulate should enable us to consider biological properties for each mucin as being relevant for others until specific functions have been elucidated. Moreover, considering the potential implication of ErbB family members, this will lead to a potential breakthrough for the design of new therapeutic strategies.

    II. Physiological and Pathological Aspects

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    II.A. Healthy Tissue Distribution and Function

    In a normal situation, TM mucins are commonly expressed and co-expressed(11,17−22) in tissues at the interface with the environment with potentially harmful conditions such as gastrointestinal, respiratory, and reproductive tracts but also in middle ear epithelium or eyes.(19,22,23) MUC4 is abundant in the normal respiratory tract, particularly in the trachea, and is also the main TM mucin component of the stomach. MUC3 is broadly expressed and quite abundant in the small intestine, while MUC12 and MUC17 are predominant in the colon. MUC3 is also noticeably present in the heart, liver, and thymus. MUC13 is expressed in the large and small intestine, stomach, esophagus, and kidney.(21) The main function of those TM mucins, in combination with secreted mucin layers, is to contribute to the development of a mucosal glycocalyx protection for epithelial cells against external aggression. They form a barrier against harsh physicochemical (pH, salinity, and temperature) or biological (enzymes, bacteria, parasites, and viruses) conditions.(4,7) Because of the presence of a cleavage site, TM mucins also exist in soluble forms to help lubrication of the lumens.(4) The noncovalent association of subunits may lead to a resistance to physical damage, the rupture of the tight link allowing the release of the energy without breaking the cell membrane.(7,22) Most TM mucins can be phosphorylated on their intracellular tails and connected to signal transduction in response to either shedding or modification of the molecules associated with their glycocalyx.(7,24) They may also be activated in response to ligand binding or protein association.(4) By interacting directly or indirectly with adhesion-associated proteins such as lectins, selectins, or integrins, they could regulate cell trafficking (cell–cell adhesion, cell–cell communication, and cell–matrix interaction).(4,25,26) Finally, they are also involved in the regulation of the cell cycle because they can induce proliferation, differentiation, or migration.(4,7,22) Among all of these functions, most are carried out by the glycans of the O-glycosylated subunit. Nevertheless, the EGF-containing mucins are involved in cell signaling and regulation processes,(27−35) in healthy conditions, from tissue regeneration, wound healing,(35) and embryogenesis and fetus development.(36,37)

    II.B. Pathological Distribution

    Mucins, and in particular TM mucins, because they have a dual function between barrier formation and signal transduction, are involved in cancer and inflammatory pathologies.(7) They are often overexpressed in epithelial cancers.(22) Noticeably, MUC4 is not expressed in healthy pancreas, whereas it is neoexpressed in the early neoplastic stage of this cancer.(17,19,28,34) In contrast, the downregulation of TM mucins may be observed in inflammatory pathologies and leads to adverse effects such as the decrease in the epithelium protective barrier(7) that can promote cancer development.(22) With regard to carcinogenesis, the implication of TM mucins is dual in the aberrant behavior of malignant cells. The proliferative and anti-apoptotic effects involve the extracellular apomucin and the cytoplasmic tail, while the invasive and anti-adhesive effects are due to the glycosylated extracellular part of the mucin.(7,38)

    III. Molecular Biology

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    III.A. Sequence Level

    Sequence data and domain assignments were retrieved from Uniprot or the literature.(17,20,39−41) The consensus sequences described for the EGF-like domains end after the sixth cysteine residue. The main structure of EGF-like domains is a major two-stranded β-sheet (Nt) followed by a loop to a minor Ct, two-stranded β-sheet. The minor sheet needs at least four residues following the last cysteine to be folded. Thus, we chose to extend our considered consensus sequences to this length.(42)
    MUC3 (Figure 1) was first described as a unique gene but was later separated in two, MUC3A and MUC3B.(40,43) MUC3B has a glycosylated subunit that is longer than that of MUC3A. With regard to their apomucin parts, they are almost identical, with only nine nonconserved residues of 369. They both consist of two EGF-like domains separated by a SEA domain that is cleaved at the GSIVV motif, right after the serine, leading to two noncovalently associated subunits. The cytoplasmic tail contains 13 serine/threonine residues and only one tyrosine that can be potentially phosphorylated on MUC3A. Finally, five potential N-glycosylated sites were characterized by an N-X-S/T motif.
    MUC4 (Figure 1) displays the largest apomucin, with notably three unique domains, NIDO, AMOP, and VWD from Nt to Ct. Two EGF-like domains are also described, named EGF1 and EGF2. EGF3 was later identified(18,28) with the six cysteine residues correctly spaced in the Nt part following EGF1. MUC4 may also be post-transcriptionally cleaved into two tightly associated subunits. This cleavage occurs at the Asp–Pro bond of the autocatalytic acid sensitive GDPH motif located at the Nt part of the VWD. Finally, MUC4 exhibits a really short cytoplasmic tail of 23 residues, with two serine residues and one tyrosine residue and 22 potential N-glycosylated sites.
    MUC12 (Figure 1) is highly homologous to MUC3, with two EGF-like domains separated by a SEA domain that displays a cleavage motif at the Ser–Ile bond of the GSIVV motif. MUC12 has only two putative N-glycosylated sites and 11 serine/threonine and two tyrosine residues (potential phosphorylation sites) within its cytoplasmic tail.
    MUC13 (Figure 1) is the shortest overall TM mucin considering its O-glycosylated subunit. The apomucin is described with three EGF-like domains, EGF1–EGF3 from Nt to Ct, with a SEA domain between EGF1 and EGF2. MUC13 is cleaved at an unknown site into two noncovalently associated subunits. The cleavage may occur at a homologous but degenerated GSVVV site as it is described for the classical SEA domain.(44) As seen for MUC3, five putative sites for N-glycosylation are reported and the cytoplasmic tail contains 13 serine/threonine residues, two tyrosines, and a protein kinase C phosphorylation motif.(45)
    Finally, MUC17 (Figure 1) is another MUC3 homologue because it displays two EGF-like domains and one SEA domain, with cleavage at the GSVVV motif.(17,44) MUC17 has five potential N-glycosylated sites and 12 serine/threonine and three tyrosine residues in its cytoplasmic tail.

    III.B. Common Features

    All of the TM mucins discussed here display at least two EGF-like domains in their structure, including conserved cysteine residues that form disulfide bonds within each domain. We previously observed that the EGF topology is conserved in the predicted structures of EGF-like domains of MUC3, MUC4, MUC12, MUC13, MUC16, and MUC17.(8) Except these conserved cysteines, EGF domains are not strongly homologous, with only the presence on the C-loop of at least one aromatic, one positive, and one negative residue.(8) Despite a low degree of overall sequence homology, previous works on the EGF–EGFR complex have shown that only a few residues of an EGF-like domain are critical for the affinity.(46) Furthermore, ErbB specificity came from distant residues located in the Ct linear region.(47)
    The SEA module is a 120-amino acid domain found in many membrane-associated proteins at the cell surface.(48) Except for MUC4, TM mucins usually contain a SEA module with a modest degree of sequence homology but a highly conserved GSXVV motif responsible for the cleavage of pro-mucins into mature mucins composed of two subunits.(44,49) No clear consensus sequence emerges from sequence alignment, because SEA domains are formed by successive helices and stranded β-sheets. Multiple N-glycosylation and O-glycosylation sites are also found in SEA domains.
    MUC4, in this regard, is described as the only TM mucin without a SEA domain. However, MUC4 possesses between EGF1 and EGF2 domains an uncharacterized domain entitled the intermediate domain (ID) that is possibly homologous with the SEA domain following sequence alignments (Figure S1). However, this alignment did not allow us to confidently state the SEA nature of the intermediate domain.
    To confirm the possibility of SEA domain homology in MUC4, we analyzed sequence conservation among various and distant MUC4 orthologs (Figure S2). A map of the conserved and nonconserved regions of MUC4 was built with this alignment. Highly conserved regions (>80% conservation over all of the found orthologs) are highlighted in purple (Figure S3). Totally nonconserved regions, where large insertions, deletions, and/or mutations were found, are highlighted in orange. Highly conserved residues can be identified either to be part of an interaction domain or to be involved in protein folding. Residues that participate in the formation of interactions with protein partners tend to co-evolve and thus exhibit a moderate variability. Our analysis of data shows that all of the most conserved residues in the Ct part of MUC4 from the CR to the EGF2 domain (Figure S3), especially the hydrophobic residues included in the ID region, exhibited characteristic patterns of helices and stranded β-sheets common to canonical and noncanonical SEA domains.(50) With this pattern, we produced an alignment of a large part of the ID of MUC4 consistent with the SEA domain. We used the characterized noncanonical SEA domain [Protein Data Bank (PDB) entry 4WIQ(50)] displaying the best homology with MUC4 as a pattern. We were able to produce a homology model by molecular modeling using this alignment (Figure 2). This model has an insertion where cleavage is usually found and exhibits a supplementary β-strand as its template. Moreover, MUC4 was shown to be proteolytically cleaved to produce a soluble form(51) in a locus other than the GDPH and within a region flanked by the two EGF-like domains. Considering this common cleavage feature, and the high probability of sequential and structural homology with canonical SEA domains, we will then consider the ID of MUC4 as a highly degenerated but still potent SEA-like domain.

    III.C. Evolutionary Track

    Our last hypothesis raises the question of a potential common evolutionary origin of these mucins. Indeed, MUC4 seems to have all of the domains (EGF and SEA-like) commonly found in other mucins. Moreover, previous works have agreed on at least three distinct origins for mucins.(2)
    Except for MUC4 and MUC16 that have been found to come from convergent evolution, MUC1, MUC3, MUC12, MUC13, and MUC17 are linked with the basement membrane-specific heparan sulfate proteoglycan core protein (HSPG2).(2) This work relied on the sequence alignment and gene homology of common domains by comparison of SEA domains of mucins and other proteins, which allowed us to link them (Figure S4). MUC4 that does not contain a classical SEA domain could not be linked with the other mucins or with HSPG2. Its NIDO–AMOP–VWD unique domains were considered and compared to the Nidogen ancestor and Susd2 as origin proteins. Another group performed evolutionary analysis by aligning the sequences of ErbB receptor natural ligands and observed a clustering of the ligands depending on their receptor specificity.(52) Our sequence analysis from EGF-containing proteins, in particular mucins, showed that MUC3, MUC4, MUC12, and MUC17 clustered together with potential ErbB2 ligands. Indeed, this study showed that EGF domains of these mucins displayed a splice site between the fourth and fifth cysteines and close to transmembrane domains. From SEA domain amino acid sequence alignment (Figure S4), we constructed a phylogenetic tree that was found to be inconclusive considering the divergence of MUC4 regarding the SEA-like domain relative to the other mucins. However, MUC1, MUC3, MUC12, and MUC17 seemed to evolve from a HSPG2 common ancestor as described previously.(2) We then explored the evolution of the only common domain among all of the proteins of interest, the EGF-like domain. It was previously described that HSPG2 could be the progenitor of the EGF domain in TM mucins by the same way as the SEA domain.(2)
    We performed the alignment of all mucin EGF-like domains with several soluble EGF ligands and protein-containing EGF domains from putative ancestors(2) (Figure S5). The 63 kDa sperm urchin membrane protein (63sp) was also included in this analysis. 63sp is one of the first proteins in which a SEA domain was observed, and its structure looks homologous to TM mucins (with an EGF–SEA–EGF module). Our analysis revealed a segregation between the differently positioned EGFs relative to the SEA domain with “EGF1” (Nt from the SEA domain) clustering together, as well as “EGF2” (Ct from the SEA domain). The EGF-like domains from HSPG2 or NIDO are probably linked, but we could not reach a conclusion about the ancestral character of those proteins (Figure 3). Moreover, none of these two proteins have an EGF domain next to a SEA domain so we could not link them further in our analysis. We generated a phylogenic tree focused only on an EGF-like domain from mucins that indicates that MUC13 seemed to be the oldest of the EGF-containing mucins with MUC4 considered as the first to have diverged. Another hypothesis could be a divergence of the MUC4/MUC13 progenitor from a common ancestor of MUC3, MUC12, and MUC17 (Figure S6). From this tree, we can also conclude that duplication produced the supplementary EGF domains (EGF3 for both MUC4 and MUC13). We noticed that the EGF3 domain of MUC4 diverges from the MUC4 EGF1 domain as well as EGF3 of MUC13, which seems to be derived from its EGF2 domain. MUC4 also possesses a fourth putative cysteine rich EGF domain, composed of six close cysteine residues that could form another EGF-like domain. This alignment suggests that it is not linked with the other EGF-like domain of MUC4 and should have a distinct origin.
    We generated a last tree from sequence alignments of SEA domain-containing mucins, including both surrounding EGF domains, to ensure that this larger homologous sequence would make our results more accurate (Figure 4). The ancestral character of MUC13 was confirmed as well as the position of MUC4 as the first to have diverged, despite its SEA domain degeneration. The position of both MUC13 and MUC4 genes on the same chromosome 3 and on the same cluster(22) strengthens this conclusion. Finally, an evolutionary study showed that genes encoding Muc13 were identified in zebrafish and chicken while the MUC4 homologous gene was found only in chicken.(53) Mucin genes localized on chromosome 7 as MUC3, MUC12, and MUC17 seem to be missing in chicken as well as in fish and might therefore reflect a more recent development in vertebrates.(53) These results confirm our hypothesis that MUC13 is the oldest mucin protein and that all others are linked due to later duplications.
    To refine even more this evolutionary sequence, a closer look at the EGF1 domain is needed. MUC13 has a classical EGF domain (six cysteine residues forming three disulfide bridges) when MUC4 has a fourth disulfide bridge.(27) It was postulated that the common ancestor of every EGF domain was a four-disulfide-bridged structure in which a bridge was shared among two consecutive domains.(42) Therefore, MUC13 and MUC4 are expected to have segregated after gene duplication, both from an integrin-like EGF domain by the loss of an extra cysteine for MUC13 and from a disulfide capture of the lone half-cysteine by a new mutated one for MUC4.
    The ancestral MUC13 or ancestral MUC4 from which the MUC3-related mucins were derived is not clear. MUC3, MUC4, MUC12, and MUC17 display only one EGF domain close to the membrane, whereas MUC13 and its orthologs exhibit a second EGF domain in this Ct part (Figure 1). Therefore, the MUC3-related mucins of a common ancestor probably seem to be closer to MUC4 than MUC13. Moreover, the Nt extended EGF1 domains of MUC3 and MUC17 share strong sequence homology. The sequence encompassing the first four cysteine residues of MUC3 closely resembles the sequence encompassing the four last cysteines (Figure 5). These observations led to the hypothesis that the common ancestor of the MUC3-related mucins resembles MUC17 that lost two cysteine residues and provided the EGF1 domain of MUC12 and MUC3. The four remaining cysteine domains were then duplicated to produce the eight cysteine domains found in both MUC3A and MUC3B. By considering the whole sequence of interest for each mucin (from the first EGF domain to the cytosolic tail), we found the same order for each mucin in the evolution of their family and undoubtedly linking MUC4 with the others (Figure S7). We also found a strong homology between MUC13 and HEG1 (another human protein with an EGF–SEA–EGF module), Mua3, MUP4 (two proteins that are found as homologues of sp63 from blast), and sp63 of sea urchin, potentially indicating a common origin with the TM mucins (Figure S8). These proteins from distant species are even closer to MUC13 than MUC4, indicating the ancestral character of MUC13 was conserved throughout evolution.

    III.D. Peculiar Features

    In addition to sharing high degrees of homology and a common structure, the TM mucins also exhibit some unique structural features. The main and common characteristics in EGF-containing proteins are the extra cysteines that tend to arise from duplicates in the EGF domain sequences. MUC13 displays an extra consensual EGF domain, directly following its EGF2 domain and preceding the transmembrane helix. Moreover, this third EGF domain contains in theory another paired cysteine occurring in the last Ct loop. The combination of these paired cysteines leading to a disulfide bridge is unknown, nor do we know how they link together or with which other cysteines present in the sequence they interact. Two of the most probable connections of the paired cysteines are 1–3, 2–4, 5–6, and 7–8 with cysteines 7 and 8 forming another loop in a manner similar to that of cysteines 5 and 6, or 1–3, 2–4, 5–8, and 6–7, with cysteines 5–8 stabilizing a large loop with two disulfide bridges (Figure 6).
    The MUC4 EGF1 domain also contains another paired cysteine for which the connectivity has yet to be elucidated. From our simulation, two main possibilities exist: 1–5, 2–4, 3–6, and 7–8, with the second cysteine of EGF1 being homologous to the first consensus cysteine from hEGF, or 1–4, 2–5, 3–6, and 7–8, with the first cysteine being homologous to the first one from hEGF (Figure 7). In both cases, an extra bridge is formed, on the B-loop, rigidifying the whole Nt and central structure.
    The MUC12 EGF1 domain encloses in its sequence only four cysteines but is still referenced as an EGF-like domain. The structure of this domain, to compensate for the loss of the disulfide bridges, is unknown, but domains structurally equivalent to EGF with only two disulfide bridges have already been elucidated (PDB entries 1AUT(54) and 5E8D(55)).
    Both MUC3A and MUC3B have extra paired cysteines in the Nt position of EGF1, but the combination is not elucidated. As postulated, the sequence enclosed by the cysteines at positions 1–4 strongly resembles that found for the four last at positions 5–8. We hypothesize that a duplication event followed by the loss of cysteines produced this EGF-like domain with eight cysteines. Another possibility could be to consider those eight cysteines not as one but as two EGF domains.
    In all mucins except MUC13, the EGF2 domains display another cysteine at position n – 4 from the first disulfide bridge and between n – 22 and n – 27 at the Nt part. MUC3-related mucins display also extra paired cysteines immediately following the Ct part of the SEA domain. Once again, the hypothetical establishment of disulfide bridges within these cysteines is unknown, as iw whether they belong to an extended EGF domain or to the SEA domain.
    Finally, MUC4 is the only TM mucin with extra and unique domains. First, 12 cysteines were noticed before the EGF1 domain with the six closest described as probably forming another EGF-like domain.(8) The six others could also theoretically form one, as well. Nevertheless, they both exhibited structural particularities that raise the question of whether they are functional or degenerate EGF domains. In addition, MUC4 has three unique domains, NIDO, AMOP, and VWD, which are highly conserved among different species, suggesting they have biological functions.(9,56,57)

    III.E. Structure–Function Relationship

    The SEA domain was first identified in highly O-glycosylated proteins and was first regarded as being involved in post-transcriptional modifications like glycosylation.(58) This domain has been identified in proteins that undergo proteolysis and more exactly by autoproteolysis mechanisms as for MUC1 or as presumed for the other SEA-containing mucins.(44,49,50) The cleavage occurs between the glycine and the serine of a retained sequence GSφφφ (where φ is an aliphatic hydrophobic residue) resulting from conformational strain.(30) All of the SEA domains exhibit the same structure, with a ferredoxin-like fold consisting of a succession of β-strands and α helices, with a sequential βαββαβ arrangement.(50) Divergent SEA domains were recently identified, with nonconserved sequences but appropriate folding.(50) It appears that SEA domains are quite tolerant to sequence divergence. The β-strands can keep up a small addition of a unique residue. Helices are tolerant to medium insertion that induces a twist. Finally, the interloops are tolerant to long insertions.(50) The autoproteolytic pattern is not necessarily conserved but sometimes is replaced by a specific protease recognition site, maintaining its ability to be cleaved. Residues other than those involved in the autoproteolysis were found to have an impact on the stabilization of the noncovalent subunit interaction(31) and on the level of N-glycosylation whose modifications disrupt mucin functions.(32)
    All TM mucins of interest exhibit the canonical SEA domain except MUC4. Nevertheless, as previously demonstrated, the DI located between EGF1 and EGF2 domains can be considered as a degenerate SEA-like domain. The main role of the SEA domain in TM mucins seems to be its cleavage into two subunits that noncovalently reassociated.(30) This mechanism would allow the release of the soluble form of the mucin, which could then act to form mucus, or as a ligand in a paracrine or exocrine process. However, inhibition of the cleavage potency of the SEA domain has abolished the whole function of the mucins regarding proliferation and migration.(32,33) There is also evidence of a second cleavage site in several mucins,(51,59) which would involve the release of a full soluble extracellular subunit and a free cytoplasmic subunit leading to transduction of the signal to the nucleus.(60)
    Another role for this SEA domain could be to form a ligand–receptor combination from a unique gene.(61) Wreschner et al. postulated that both subunits resulting from SEA cleavage act as a ligand–receptor couple, with dynamic association/dissociation.(61) Both events would then induce modification of the transmembrane part, leading to signal transduction, regulation of cell–cell interaction or immune cell recognition, and detection of bacteria.(61,62) This mechanism could also protect the cell against physical rupture by breaking. Indeed, when a cell faces an external force that could lead to the rupture of the membrane, this force can be dissipated by the cleavage of mucins at the level of their SEA domain, safeguarding the cell membrane.
    EGF domains are structurally well-defined and widespread domains, as they are found in almost all living organisms and viruses.(42) EGF domains are considered as ancestral proteins derived from the first tertiary structures that proteins have adopted. Several subclasses of EGF domains exist, with differences in loop length or cysteine number or positioning. They almost all share at least five homologous cysteines and one found to be topologically homologous that form three highly conserved disulfide bridges. These bridges lead to the canonic structure of the EGF domains and can be described as follows. The Nt part whose structure is EGF domain-dependent is followed by the A-loop. Then two β-strands separated from each other by the B-loop shape a major β-sheet followed by the C-loop, a very short minor stranded β-sheet, and finally the Ct part.(42) Apart from these disulfide bridges, EGF domains exhibit very little to no sequence conservation. We can still notice some exceptions. The presence of hydrophobic residues located just next to the first two cysteines is needed to ensure a correct folding(63) as well as some conserved glycine residues whose mutation leads to the unfolded domain.(64)
    EGF domains are involved in a wide range of functions such as serving as ligands for cell signaling or coagulation or in protein–protein interactions (PPIs). They were also found as spacers in large clusters of repetitive duplicated domains or in a mosaic assembly with other domains.(42) We will focus on a particular functional subclass of EGF domains, those acting as ErbB receptor ligands. A dozen soluble EGF domains have been described as ligands for a member of the ErbB family such as ErbB1 (EGFR), ErbB3, or ErbB4 but none for ErbB2. Close comparison at the sequence level did not lead to a clear consensus conserved pattern. A conserved hydrophobic region was found around the second cysteine, but only the arginine located just before the last cysteine seems to be crucial for ErbB affinity.(65) This arginine can be replaced with a polar ionic residue but with a loss of affinity for the ErbB receptor.(52,64,66) In addition to these aa clusters, other residues are important for the specificity of receptor recognition by negative constraints, especially in both of the terminal linear regions.(47,67) It was indeed demonstrated that a pan-ErbB ligand, noted panerbin, could be produced with the sequence of EGF fused with the terminal region of neuregulin. Therefore, specificity seems to be more a result of negative regulation from those terminal regions than from sequence hot spots. Finally, other common criteria allow us to discern ErbB receptor ligands, like the presence of a splicing site between the fourth and fifth cysteines and membrane proximity.(52) Currently, three of the five mucins cited (MUC4, MUC13, and MUC17) have been shown to interact with ErbB2, a member of the ErbB family without identified soluble ligands, and this has consequences for proliferation, migration, and differentiation in normal and cancer cells.(25,28,29,33)

    IV. MUC/ErbB2 Complexes

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    ErbB2 belongs to the ErbB family, which incudes EGFR (ErbB1), ErbB3, and ErbB4.(52) ErbB2 is a receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) but with many unique features compared to its close homologues. The three other ErbB receptors exist in a tethered monomeric inactive conformation and can bind several specific soluble ligands to shift toward an extended conformation that have a propensity to form active homo- and heterodimers.(68) No soluble ligand is known for ErbB2, which, moreover, does not expose a tethered conformation and seems to be constitutively in an active pro-dimeric conformation. Due to the absence of ligand regulation, it is also believed to be “poised” to interact and form heterodimers and act as the preferential partner for the other ErbBs.(68)
    A computational study of ErbB2 led to a slightly different conclusion.(68) The authors compared the crystallographic structure of ErbB2 with that of Drosophila EGFR (dEGFR). They could observe striking similarities between both crystallographic data, with dEGFR not having a tethered conformation. dEGFR exists in an autoinhibited conformation that relies on interaction between domains I and III of the extracellular part of the receptor, instead of domains II and IV found in other mammalian ErbBs. This conformation closes the binding pocket in the absence of a ligand in a manner similar to that of the conformation adopted by free ErbB2. Therefore, ErbB2 seems to be the closest homologue relative to the ErbB invertebrate family. Nevertheless, dEGFR has four soluble ligands that need to be palmitoylated to be active and consequently associated with the membrane, like MUC4, the membrane-bound partner of ErbB2.(68) The authors conclude that far from being always in an open unregulated conformation, ErbB2 would exhibit an autoinhibited conformation with a larger buried surface and a more restrictive regulation than for the other ErbBs.(68) In light of these conclusions, the implication of the TM mucins as ligands(69) or membrane partners for ErbB2 opens a totally new field in the ErbB2 targeting pathway.

    IV.A. Which Mucin?

    Every EGF-containing TM mucin has been involved in carcinogenesis, by either up- or downregulation mechanisms,(8,19,34,35,70−72) and some of them were described as interfering with the ErbB2 pathway. The most studied is MUC4 and its rat and mouse orthologs, which have been proven to interact directly with ErbB2.(25,28,73,74) Recently, a mirror function has been found for MUC13.(29) In another study that focused on the autoproteolytic function of the SEA domain of rMUC3 (now described as the homologue of the human MUC17 ortholog), the authors found that rMUC3 promoted proliferation depending on its interaction with ErbB2.(33) From the five members of the EGF-containing TM mucin family of interest in this review, three have already been shown to be partners of ErbB2. We can then strongly postulate that all of the mucins of this subfamily could interact with ErbB2 or another ErbB family member. Unlike most membrane-bound mucins, MUC1 lacks EGF-like domains. Despite this, MUC1 interacts with EGFR at the plasma membrane.(75) This interaction is weakened when MUC1 lacks its cytoplasmic tail.(76) MUC1 also regulates EGFR trafficking and nuclear accumulation and chromatin binding regardless of the exogenous ligand.(77) An indirect interaction of MUC1 and EGFR has also been demonstrated in different works(78,79) and implies galectin-3 that anchors the bridge between glycosylated Asn36-MUC1 and EGFR.(80) MUC1 also physically binds with ErbB2, ErbB3, and ErbB4 following heregulin stimulation.(81)

    IV.B. With Whom?

    MUC4 is involved in the induction of proliferation and migration via direct interaction with ErbB2. The main partner of ErbB2 and its own ligands, ErbB3 and the neuregulins (Neu), respectively, must also be considered. The ErbB2/ErbB3/Neu complex is described as being strongly oncogenic and involved in tumorigenesis. In a normal polarized cell, there is segregation of the members of the MUC4/ErbB2/ErbB3/NRG complex.(74) In a polarized cell without MUC4, ErbB2 and ErbB3 are on the basolateral pole but the ligands of ErbB3 are available only at the apical level, avoiding the formation of the heterodimer. In the presence of MUC4, ErbB2 is relocated at the apical level, allowing complexation of both proteins but prohibiting the complexation with ErbB3 because it is still basolateral. Following loss of cell polarity, which occurs frequently in cancer cells, the association of MUC4 with ErbB2 induces partial phosphorylation of ErbB2 on two sites, Tyr1139 and Tyr1248.(82) When ErbB3/Neu is added to the complex, the phosphorylation of ErbB2 is extended to ErbB3 allowing activation of two major signaling pathways involved in cell proliferation and differentiation as PI3K/AKt and p38, respectively.(27) MUC4 seems to induce extended and robust phosphorylation of both ErbBs by stabilizing the four-partner complex at the cell membrane and relocating both ErbBs from the intracellular compartment to the membrane.(27) Furthermore, this complex is associated with resistance to apoptosis and also resistance to chemotherapy.(27,83,84) All of these results point to an overactivation of the ErbB2 pathway following interaction with MUC4, linking the experimental evidence with human cancer pathogenesis. The same mechanism is drawn for the protein complex between MUC13 and ErbB2 leading to cell proliferation, migration, invasion, and resistance to apoptosis.(29,34,85,86) rMUC3, strongly homologous to MUC17, also promotes proliferation, migration, and resistance to apoptosis(35) that could be directly linked to ErbB2.(33) Nevertheless, its proliferative aspect is considered here as a possibility for healing intestinal ulcers, emphasizing the dual aspect between aberrant proliferation encountered in cancer cells and its protective aspect in terms of inflammatory diseases.
    Recently, a new involvement of ErbB3 was discovered because in the absence of ErbB2, a direct interaction between MUC4 and ErbB3 could be observed, with oncogenic effects.(87) MUC4, and the other TM mucins, with their multiple EGFs domains, could therefore activate several different pathways depending on the cellular context, making them even more of a pivot to target to inhibit several oncogenic pathways.

    IV.C. How?

    The physical interaction between EGF-containing TM mucins and ErbB2 needs to be elucidated to design and propose new therapeutics in the clinical setting. While the three-dimensional structure of the ErbB2 receptor has been determined well (PDB entry 3WLW(88)), no structural data for TM mucins are available. The understanding of the mechanisms of interaction must then rely on homology modeling and the following hypotheses.
    First, we have supposed that interaction between TM mucins and ErbB receptors is mediated by the EGF-like domains forming a complex homologous to that described for EGFR–EGF(46) or dEGFR–spitz.(89) The crucial role played by the EGF–SEA–EGF module(28,35,90) argues in favor of such a case and was further demonstrated by our work. Indeed, we have shown that the truncated mutant encompassing only the EGF domains of MUC4 was necessary to provide efficient interaction with ErbB2.(73) Data on MUC13 have shown that only the EGF domains surrounding the SEA domain were active and the deletion of EGF3, the EGF domain closest to the membrane, did not disturb interaction.(29)
    While various EGF-containing TM mucins were able to bind to the same ErbB receptor, no common structural features have been identified between the constitutive EGF-like domains of these mucins. The first hypothesis suggested that isolated EGF domains were not sufficient to interact with ErbB2 or were considered as ErbB2 ligands with low affinity. Similar to the case for the dEGFR ligands, they may be required to be membrane-bound to exhibit their full biological activity. As previously described, EGF-containing TM mucins consist of a central core extended in the Nt and Ct parts by regulatory regions. While the central core would be responsible for the ErbB activation, the regulatory regions could be involved in receptor specificity. Indeed, as detailed previously, both of the terminal regions are critical for the receptor specificity, providing a negative regulation. Specificity of TM mucins for ErbB2 may then come from an outer region, with the SEA domain being the most probable candidate that is common to all TM mucins.
    Another hypothesis would be to consider that a wider interface is needed. The SEA domain, shared by all of the EGF-containing TM mucins, could be part of the interaction with ErbB2 either by performing the correct folding of the EGF domains or by acting as a chaperone protein. The SEA domain could also interact with ErbB2 in a recognition site, positioning the EGF domains close to their binding sites or modifying the folding of ErbB2 by supplying the required energy leading to its open state. Evidence that the SEA domain is involved in the interaction with ErbB2 was demonstrated by the inhibition of both half-protein activity resulting from a chemical bond breaking in the SEA domain of rMUC3.(35) Those data strongly suggest that EGF-containing TM mucins need the full length EGF–SEA–EGF module to confer their biological activity. Indeed, modification of the SEA domain, impairment of its autocatalytic function, or the SEA domain alone did not demonstrate any biological activity.(33,90) The overall hypothesis remains contested because MUC13 was described to need only one EGF domain to have the full biological activity(29) or only the EGF1 domain of MUC4 was sufficient to observe co-immunoprecipitation.(91)
    These results suggest a dual mechanism for each mucin, with an activity carried by only the EGF domains and another carried by a larger interface leading to the formation of a larger complex and enhancing the cellular response. Regardless, a tight link seems to exist between the EGF domains and the adjacent SEA domain. Our hypothesis is that both EGF and SEA domains have achieved co-evolution until they become a single module, with functions different from those of the isolated domains.(92) The fact that SEA domains were not found to be able to exchange among the various mucins(44) reinforces the hypothesis suggesting the importance of EGF and SEA domain folding or of a more complex tertiary folding with a common interface, including intrachain interactions. This extended ligand interface could have co-evolved with ErbB2(52) to avoid cross-interaction with other EGF/ErbBs.

    V. Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    V.A. EGF and Human Pathophysiology

    A large number of questions still need to be answered about the EGF-containing TM mucins. From a molecular biology point of view, elucidation of the structure and insight into the interplay between EGF and SEA domains may lead to a better understanding of their exact role. From these differences, specificities and unique functions could be discovered. Their function as an ErbB2 partner opens an entire new therapeutic field about this RTK that is often overexpressed in cancer. However, this partnership could also be exploited for its powerful regenerative properties, in inflammatory diseases as well as in degenerative pathologies, by selectively activating the appropriate array of ErbB2 signaling pathway.
    MUC4 and MUC13 are described as well-validated targets for cancer therapy, in particular for pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Both mucins are not expressed in healthy pancreas but are overexpressed in pancreatic adenocarcinoma,(34,93) in which they drive the aggressiveness of cancer cells in an ErbB2-dependent way that can be reverted by silencing.(34,94) Furthermore, a proof of concept of the strategy targeting those mucins has already been demonstrated. miRNA as a negative regulator for both has been shown to be a tumor suppressor in pancreatic cancer.(95,96) Those results pave the way for the development of therapeutics targeting the mucin–ErbB complex in cancers.

    V.B. TM Mucins as Promising Therapeutic Targets

    We have revealed in this review that EGF-containing TM mucins, involved in the deleterious process of cancer or inflammatory diseases, were membrane partners of the oncogenic receptor ErbB2. We have also exposed a large body of evidence on their structural convergence, as well as solid hypotheses about the implications of EGF and SEA domains for the interaction with ErbB2. Disturbance or inhibition of the interaction between TM mucins and ErbB receptors represents a new potential therapeutic area in the treatment of epithelium-derived pathologies. Targeting an EGF-like domain, mostly globular, with drugs constitutes a challenging task. The involvement of the SEA domain as well as the evidence for a tight relationship between SEA and EGF domains in the formation of a unique module could reveal a more druggable interface. In a similar way, studies of rMUC3/MUC17 have shown that modification of the SEA domain could impair the activity of the mucin. Altogether, this review highlights several potential sites on EGF-containing TM mucins to be targeted (Figure 8). (1) The direct inhibition targeting the EGF domains by an antibody strategy. If different EGFs induce various cell responses or activate the formation of different dimers, this could help to ensure specific inhibition. (2) Targeting of an allosteric site by small organic molecules. The SEA domain is larger and more adaptable than an EGF domain. Therefore, a putative druggable binding site could be targeted, leading to misfolding of the protein and disruption of the interaction with the ErbB2 receptor. (3) Inhibition of MUC-ErbB2 PPI. Both EGF and SEA domains seem to interact together with ErbB2 forming a delocalized and dual epitope as the binding interface. Both epitopes can be contiguous and form a broader druggable interface that could be targeted by PPI inhibitors. (4) Stabilizing the autocatalytic loop involved in the cleavage of the SEA domain. As disruption of the cleavage of the SEA domain can presumably abolish the activity of the mucins, this strategy could lead to a proper inhibition of the mucin-induced pathways. (5) Disruption or stabilization of the noncovalent intramolecular interactions of the SEA domain. Following the hypothesis of a dual receptor–ligand generated by the SEA domain,(61) this strategy could modulate the activity of the mucin, provided that the existence and biological significance of this hypothesis are validated. (6) Inhibition of SEA–EGF domain PPI. We raised the hypothesis that there could be a binding interface between one EGF domain and part of the SEA domain. Disruption of this interaction with PPI inhibitors could impair the proper folding of this module and then the formation of the MUC–ErbB2 complex.

    V.C. ErbB2 PPI Interface as a Promising Therapeutic Target

    ErbB2 targeting by antibodies or catalytic tyrosine kinase inhibitors suffers from a lack of efficiency in some cancers, like in pancreatic adenocarcinoma or breast cancer, and often triggers resistance mechanisms.(83,97,98) Due to its partnership with the EGF-containing TM mucins, ErbB2 exhibits increased pro-oncogenic properties. We propose two new and promising pathways for disrupting the deleterious effect of ErbB2 oncogenic signaling: (1) targeting specific interfaces on ErbB2 binding sites involved in interaction with EGF-containing TM mucins, focusing on epitopes different from those currently targeted using antibodies, and (2) stabilizing the closed conformation of ErbB2 to prevent any interaction with a possible partner. The second option presents several advantages. ErbB2 RTK is a key regulator leading to multiple intracellular signaling pathways. Drugs that block or attenuate RTK activity by targeting its extracellular epitope would reduce the possibility of resistance involving parallel bypass signaling pathways. Second, targeting ErbB2 could produce a pan-mucin inhibition that would avoid a shift from one mucin to another (redundancy), as in pancreatic adenocarcinoma in which both MUC4 and MUC13 are overexpressed. Finally, inhibition of the TM mucin–ErbB2 complex will only lower the oncogenicity of ErbB2 and not abolish it totally, as ErbB2 should still be able to heterodimerize with other ErbB domains. Only the overaggressiveness of the adjunction of mucins with ErbB2 would be suppressed. This strategy should induce less stress in the cancer cells and presumably reduce the possibility of the occurrence of resistance. Indeed, therapies targeting ErbB2 met many resistance mechanisms despite good therapeutic results, often with the emergence of bypass signaling pathways or target alterations.(99,100) In this regard, targeting mucins would only eliminate the detrimental effect of the overexpression of the mucins without altering the normal functionality of ErbB2 or other RTK domains. Moreover, this strategy may allow the use of ErbB2-targeted therapy with a synergistic outcome.

    V.D. Concluding Remarks: Just the Tip of the Iceberg

    This review has identified the EGF–SEA–EGF module as a common module shared among a class of TM mucins. Moreover, this module was also found in a protein from sea urchin. It was also found in two proteins from Caenorhabditis elegans, MUP4 and Mua3. Two Drosophila homologues were also identified. In humans, several possible homologues could also be found, some with the full motif, like HEG1 or UROL, and some with only a SEA–EGF module. Among those, one (NGC) is already characterized to bind ErbB3, and another, HEG1, is potentially a partner of ErbB2. A rootless tree built with these modules shows strong evidence of an evolutionary link among all of these proteins (Figure 9).
    A systematic alignment of EGF ligands and EGF domains associated with SEA from invertebrate or human proteins showed a common feature. The soluble ligands clustered with the EGF juxtamembrane domain (Figure S9). This clustering exists from invertebrates to humans, despite differences in the clade or numbers of receptor/ligand couples. It raises the hypothesis that the soluble EGF could be more recent than the TM mucins with the EGF–SEA–EGF module. The partnership between TM mucins and ErbB could be then an ancestral feature and now be frequent and represent a complete set of modulators for ErbB/RTK signaling. This could be a whole shadow pathway of transient signaling, potentially responsible for some resistance phenomena with cancer therapies.
    In summary, we have identified a new subfamily of TM mucins containing EGF and SEA domains potentially sharing common structure–function relationships. This subfamily of SEA- and EGF-containing TM mucins (SEA–EGF TM mucins) demonstrated its capacity to be a membrane partner of the ErbB receptor, in particular with ErbB2, which has yet to have an identified ligand. Interest in targeting the SEA–EGF TM mucin–ErbB complex has already been partially demonstrated for MUC4 and MUC13 with ErbB2. Here, we present several strategies for targeting SEA–EGF TM mucin–ErbB complexes in cancer that should lead to a major breakthrough in the future.

      Mucin glycoproteins
      Walker-Nasir, Evelyne; Ahmad, Ishtiaq; Hoessli, Daniel C.; Shakoori, A. R.; Nasir-ud-Din
      Proceedings of the Pakistan Academy of Sciences (2003), 40 (2), 205-232CODEN: PKSPAW; ISSN:0377-2969. (Pakistan Academy of Sciences)
      A review discusses mucin glycoproteins, their classification, phys. and biochem. properties, gene expression and regulation, biosynthesis, and their role in normal physiol. and in disease.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXotFyntw%253D%253D&md5=9a9d79271e467ab275eefd0c1da000f5
    2. 2
      Duraisamy, S.; Ramasamy, S.; Kharbanda, S.; Kufe, D. Distinct Evolution of the Human Carcinoma-Associated Transmembrane Mucins, MUC1, MUC4 AND MUC16. Gene 2006, 373, 28– 34,  DOI: 10.1016/j.gene.2005.12.021
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Distinct evolution of the human carcinoma-associated transmembrane mucins, MUC1, MUC4 and MUC16
      Duraisamy, Sekhar; Ramasamy, Selvi; Kharbanda, Surender; Kufe, Donald
      Gene (2006), 373 (), 28-34CODEN: GENED6; ISSN:0378-1119. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The MUC family of mucins consists of secreted and membrane-bound forms. Overexpression of the membrane-bound family members, MUC1 (CA15-3), MUC4 and MUC16 (CA125), is found in diverse human carcinomas. However, despite being classified in the same family, little is known about the genetic origins of the carcinoma-assocd. mucins. The present results show that MUC1 homologs are restricted to mammalian species. MUC1 has no sequence similarity with the other membrane-bound mucins, except for the presence of a sea urchin sperm protein-enterokinase-agrin (SEA) domain. The results indicate that the MUC1 SEA domain originated from heparin sulfate proteoglycan of basement membrane (HSPG2; perlecan), an inducer of tumor cell growth. MUC4 has no SEA domain, but does have (i) a NIDO domain that evolved from an ancestor common to nidogen, and (ii) AMOP and VWD domains that originated from an ancestor common to the Sushi-domain contg. protein. MUC16 contains multiple SEA domains that are found in a chicken gene and were subsequently repeated through duplication events. The SEA domains in MUC16 appear to have evolved from agrin before the divergence of birds and mammals. These findings indicate that MUC1, MUC4 and MUC16 evolved from distinct ancestors and that the membrane-bound mucins consist of different subgroups based on their genetic backgrounds.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xktlaqu7w%253D&md5=61372ada19695f06903e5eb795e762a0
    3. 3
      Corfield, A. P. Mucins: a Biologically Relevant Glycan Barrier in Mucosal Protection. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Gen. Subj. 2015, 1850, 236– 252,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bbagen.2014.05.003
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Mucins: A biologically relevant glycan barrier in mucosal protection
      Corfield, Anthony P.
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, General Subjects (2015), 1850 (1), 236-252CODEN: BBGSB3; ISSN:0304-4165. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. The mucins found as components of mucus gel layers at mucosal surfaces throughout the body play roles in protection as part of the defensive barrier on an organ and tissue specific basis. The human MUC gene family codes up to 20 known proteins, which can be divided into secreted and membrane-assocd. forms each with a typical protein domain structure. The secreted mucins are adapted to cross link in order to allow formation of the extended mucin networks found in the secreted mucus gels. The membrane-assocd. mucins possess membrane specific domains which enable their various biol. functions as part of the glycocalyx. All mucins are highly O-glycosylated and this is tissue specific and linked with specific biol. functions at these locations. Mucin biol. is dynamic and the processes of degrdn. and turnover are well integrated with biosynthesis to maintain a continuous mucosal protection against all external aggressive forces. Interaction of mucins with microflora plays an important role in normal function. Mucins are modified in a variety of diseases and this may be due to abberant mucin peptide or glycosylation. Mucins represent a family of glycoprotein having fundamental roles in mucosal protection and communication with external environment. The review emphasizes the nature of mucins as glycoproteins and their role in presenting an array of glycan structures at the mucosal cell surface.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtlOltbzL&md5=c30f2b809562ef2945cb3e3a13a72b1c
    4. 4
      Hollingsworth, M. A.; Swanson, B. J. Mucins in Cancer: Protection and Control of the Cell Surface. Nat. Rev. Cancer 2004, 4, 45– 60,  DOI: 10.1038/nrc1251
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Mucins in cancer: protection and control of the cell surface
      Hollingsworth, Michael A.; Swanson, Benjamin J.
      Nature Reviews Cancer (2004), 4 (1), 45-60CODEN: NRCAC4; ISSN:1474-175X. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Mucins - large extracellular proteins that are heavily glycosylated with complex oligosaccharides - establish a selective mol. barrier at the epithelial surface and engage in morphogenetic signal transduction. Alterations in mucin expression or glycosylation accompany the development of cancer and influence cellular growth, differentiation, transformation, adhesion, invasion and immune surveillance. Mucins are used as diagnostic markers in cancer, and are under investigation as therapeutic targets for cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXpvVGnu7w%253D&md5=26a6f24250cb21c6cd2a707c3b9f9790
    5. 5
      Bartman, A. E.; Buisine, M. P.; Aubert, J. P.; Niehans, G. A.; Toribara, N. W.; Kim, Y. S.; Kelly, E. J.; Crabtree, J. E.; Ho, S. B. The MUC6 Secretory Mucin Gene is Expressed in a Wide Variety ofEpithelial Tissues. J. Pathol. 1998, 186, 398– 405,  DOI: 10.1002/(SICI)1096-9896(199812)186:4<398::AID-PATH192>3.0.CO;2-X
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      The MUC6 secretory mucin gene is expressed in a wide variety of epithelial tissues
      Bartman, Allen E.; Buisine, Marie-Pierre; Aubert, Jean-Pierre; Niehans, Gloria A.; Toribara, Neil W.; Kim, Young S.; Kelly, Eric J.; Crabtree, Jean E.; Ho, Samuel B.
      Journal of Pathology (1998), 186 (4), 398-405CODEN: JPTLAS; ISSN:0022-3417. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
      Secretory mucins play an important role in the cytoprotection of epithelial surfaces and are used as tumor markers in a variety of cancers. The MUC6 secretory mucin was originally isolated from a gastric cDNA library. The aim was to det. the specific type and location of MUC6 mucin gene expression in a wide range of human adult and fetal epithelial tissues. In situ hybridization, RNA anal., and immunohistochem. were used to quantify and localize mucin gene expression. The data obtained show that MUC6 is highly expressed in gastric mucosa, duodenal Brunner's glands, gall bladder, seminal vesicle, pancreatic centroacinar cells and ducts, and periductal glands of the common bile duct; focal expression is seen in basal endometrial and endocervical glands. MUC6 epitopes were also highly expressed in 7/10 pancreatic cancers and 7/10 cholangiocarcinomas and focally expressed in 4/10 endocervical adenocarcinomas. Expression of MUC6 occurs early in fetal development and was obsd. in Brunner's glands and pancreatic ducts at 18-19 wk and in gastric glands at 20 wk' gestation. The tissue distribution of the MUC6 secretory mucin indicates that it may function to protect epithelial tissues from a wide range of substances. Expression of MUC6 is frequently preserved in pancreatic and bile duct adenocarcinomas, but it is only sparsely expressed in endocervical carcinomas.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXmtVyisg%253D%253D&md5=a4a42b210261a58f91de2d5332ae43ae

      Forstner, J. F. Intestinal Mucins in Health and Disease. Digestion 2004, 17, 234– 263,  DOI: 10.1159/000198115
      [Crossref], Google Scholar

    7. 7
      van Putten, J. P. M.; Strijbis, K. Transmembrane Mucins: Signaling Receptors at the Intersection of Inflammation and Cancer. J. Innate Immun. 2017, 9, 281– 299,  DOI: 10.1159/000453594
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Transmembrane Mucins: Signaling Receptors at the Intersection of Inflammation and Cancer
      van Putten, Jos P. M.; Strijbis, Karin
      Journal of Innate Immunity (2017), 9 (3), 281-299CODEN: JIIOB2; ISSN:1662-811X. (S. Karger AG)
      Mucosal surfaces line our body cavities and provide the interaction surface between commensal and pathogenic microbiota and the host. The barrier function of the mucosal layer is largely maintained by gel-forming mucin proteins that are secreted by goblet cells. In addn., mucosal epithelial cells express cell-bound mucins that have both barrier and signaling functions. The family of transmembrane mucins consists of diverse members that share a few characteristics. The highly glycosylated extracellular mucin domains inhibit invasion by pathogenic bacteria and can form a tight mesh structure that protects cells in harmful conditions. The intracellular tails of transmembrane mucins can be phosphorylated and connect to signaling pathways that regulate inflammation, cell-cell interactions, differentiation, and apoptosis. Transmembrane mucins play important roles in preventing infection at mucosal surfaces, but are also renowned for their contributions to the development, progression, and metastasis of adenocarcinomas. In general, transmembrane mucins seem to have evolved to monitor and repair damaged epithelia, but these functions can be highjacked by cancer cells to yield a survival advantage. This review presents an overview of the current knowledge of the functions of transmembrane mucins in inflammatory processes and carcinogenesis in order to better understand the diverse functions of these multifunctional proteins.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXntFeisbo%253D&md5=d38d559090bd6d2e3ef174d7f1254edf
    8. 8
      Jonckheere, N.; Skrypek, N.; Frenois, F.; Van Seuningen, I. Membrane-Bound Mucin Modular Domains: from Structure to Function. Biochimie 2013, 95, 1077– 1086,  DOI: 10.1016/j.biochi.2012.11.005
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Membrane-bound mucin modular domains: From structure to function
      Jonckheere, Nicolas; Skrypek, Nicolas; Frenois, Frederic; Van Seuningen, Isabelle
      Biochimie (2013), 95 (6), 1077-1086CODEN: BICMBE; ISSN:0300-9084. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      A review. Mucins belong to a heterogeneous family of large O-glycoproteins composed of a long peptidic chain called apomucin on which are linked hundreds of oligosaccharidic chains. Among mucins, membrane-bound mucins are modular proteins and have a structural organization usually contg. Pro/Thr/Ser-rich O-glycosylated domains (PTS), EGF-like and SEA domains. Via these modular domains, the membrane-bound mucins participate in cell signaling and cell interaction with their environment in normal and pathol. conditions. Moreover, the recent knowledge of these domains and their biol. activities led to the development of new therapeutic approaches involving mucins. In this review, we show 3D structures of EGF and SEA domains. We also describe the functional features of the evolutionary conserved domains of membrane-bound mucins and discuss consequences of splice events.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhslynu7nM&md5=8d88b659cf4fba257cd8d70bbbc40690
    9. 9
      Zhu, Y.; Zhang, J.-J.; Peng, Y.-P.; Liu, X.; Xie, K.-L.; Tang, J.; Jiang, K.-R.; Gao, W.-T.; Tian, L.; Zhang, K.; Xu, Z.-K.; Miao, Y. NIDO, AMOP and Vwd Domains of MUC4 Play Synergic Role in MUC4 Mediated Signaling. Oncotarget 2017, 8, 10385– 10399,  DOI: 10.18632/oncotarget.14420
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      NIDO, AMOP and vWD domains of MUC4 play synergic role in MUC4 mediated signaling
      Zhu Yi; Zhang Jing-Jing; Peng Yun-Peng; Liu Xian; Jiang Kui-Rong; Gao Wen-Tao; Tian Lei; Zhang Kai; Miao Yi; Zhu Yi; Zhang Jing-Jing; Peng Yun-Peng; Liu Xian; Jiang Kui-Rong; Gao Wen-Tao; Tian Lei; Zhang Kai; Miao Yi; Zhu Yi; Zhang Jing-Jing; Peng Yun-Peng; Liu Xian; Xie Kun-Ling; Tang Jie; Jiang Kui-Rong; Gao Wen-Tao; Tian Lei; Zhang Kai; Xu Ze-Kuan; Miao Yi; Xie Kun-Ling; Tang Jie
      Oncotarget (2017), 8 (6), 10385-10399 ISSN:.
      MUC4 mucin is well known as an important potential target to overcome pancreatic cancer. Three unique domains (NIDO, AMOP, and vWD) with unclear roles only present in MUC4 but are not found in other membrane-bound mucins. Our previous studies first reported that its splice variant, MUC4/Y can be a model of MUC4 (MUC4 gene fragment is more than 30KB, too huge to clone and eukaryotic express) in pancreatic cancer. More importantly, based on MUC4/Y with the appropriate length of gene sequence, it is easy to construct the unique domain-lacking models of MUC4/Y (MUC4) for research. The present study focuses on investigation of the respective role of the unique NIDO, AMOP, and vWD domain or their synergistic effect on MUC4(MUC4/Y)-mediated functions and mechanisms by series of in vitro assays, sequence-based transcriptome analysis, validation of qRT-PCR & Western blot, and systematic comparative analysis. Our results demonstrate: 1) NIDO, AMOP, and vWD domain or their synergy play significant roles on MUC4/Y-mediated malignant function of pancreatic cancer, downstream of molecule mechanisms, particularly MUC4/Y-triggered malignancy-related positive feedback loops, respectively. 2) The synergistic roles of three unique domains on MUC4/Y-mediated functions and mechanisms are more prominent than the respective domain because the synergy of three domain plays the more remarkable effects on MUC4/Y-mediated signaling hub. Thus, to improve reversed effects of domain-lacking and break the synergism of domains will contribute to block MUC4/Y(MUC4) triggering various oncogenic signaling pathways.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1c7jtVOmug%253D%253D&md5=30def6751b6cd7fd6d22524f69f7721e
    10. 10
      Duraisamy, S.; Kufe, T.; Ramasamy, S.; Kufe, D. Evolution of the Human MUC1 Oncoprotein. Int. J. Oncol. 2007, 31, 671– 677,  DOI: 10.3892/ijo.31.3.671
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Evolution of the human MUC1 oncoprotein
      Duraisamy, Sekhar; Kufe, Turner; Ramasamy, Selvi; Kufe, Donald
      International Journal of Oncology (2007), 31 (3), 671-677CODEN: IJONES; ISSN:1019-6439. (International Journal of Oncology)
      The mucin (MUC) family consists of secreted and membrane-bound forms. The transmembrane mucin 1 (MUC1) is a heterodimer that is aberrantly overexpressed by diverse human carcinomas and certain hematol. malignancies. The MUC1 N-terminal (MUC1-N) and C-terminal (MUC1-C) subunits are generated by autocleavage within a SEA domain. The MUC1 cytoplasmic domain (MUC 1-CD) located downstream of the SEA domain is sufficient for the induction of anchorage-independent growth and tumorigenicity; however, no information is available regarding the origin of these transforming sequences. Previous work demonstrated that, except for the SEA domain, MUC1 has no sequence homol. with other membrane-bound mucins. The present results demonstrate that MUC 1-CD evolved from repeat regions in the MUC5B secreted mucin. We also show that MUC1 sequences upstream to the SEA domain emerged from MUC5B. These findings indicate that both the MUC1-N and MUC1-C subunits evolved from secreted gel-forming mucins and that the MUC 1-CD oncogenic function emerged by diversification after evolution from MUC5B.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtVagurnF&md5=4b59c367d8685388d60c5d576675aa55
    11. 11
      Jonckheere, N.; Skrypek, N.; Van Seuningen, I. Mucins and Pancreatic Cancer. Cancers 2010, 2, 1794– 1812,  DOI: 10.3390/cancers2041794
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Mucins and Pancreatic cancer
      Jonckheere, Nicolas; Skrypek, Nicolas; Van Seuningen, Isabelle
      Cancers (2010), 2 (), 1794-1812CODEN: CANCCT; ISSN:2072-6694. (Molecular Diversity Preservation International)
      A review. Pancreatic cancer is characterized by an often dramatic outcome (five year survival <5%) related to a late diagnosis and a lack of efficient therapy. Therefore, clinicians desperately need new biomarkers and new therapeutic tools to develop new efficient therapies. Mucins belong to an ever increasing family of O-glycoproteins. Secreted mucins are the main component of mucus protecting the epithelia whereas membrane-bound mucins are thought to play important biol. roles in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions, in cell signaling and in modulating biol. properties of cancer cells. In this review, we will focus on the altered expression pattern of mucins in pancreatic cancer, from the early neoplastic lesion Pancreatic Intraepithelial Neoplasia (PanIN) to invasive pancreatic carcinomas, and the mol. mechanisms (including genetic and epigenetic regulation) and signaling pathways known to control their expression. Moreover, we will discuss the recent advances about the biol. of both secreted and membrane-bound mucins and their key roles in pancreatic carcinogenesis and resistance to therapy. Finally, we will discuss exciting opportunities that mucins offer as potential therapeutic targets in pancreatic cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsVWksrnL&md5=f3e8517a154d4f38d63112fbb0584155
    12. 12
      Jonckheere, N.; Skrypek, N.; Van Seuningen, I. Mucins and Tumor Resistance to Chemotherapeutic Drugs. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Rev. Cancer 2014, 1846, 142– 151,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bbcan.2014.04.008
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Mucins and tumor resistance to chemotherapeutic drugs
      Jonckheere, Nicolas; Skrypek, Nicolas; Van Seuningen, Isabelle
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Reviews on Cancer (2014), 1846 (1), 142-151CODEN: BBACEU; ISSN:0304-419X. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Epithelial cancer patients not considered eligible for surgical resection frequently benefit from chemotherapy. Chemotherapy is the treatment of cancer with one or combination of cytotoxic or cytostatic drugs. Recent advances in chemotherapy allowed a great no. of cancer patients to receive treatment with significant results. Unfortunately, resistance to chemotherapeutic drug treatment is a major challenge for clinicians in the majority of epithelial cancers because it is responsible for the inefficiency of therapies. Mucins belong to a heterogeneous group of large O-glycoproteins that can be either secreted or membrane-bound. Implications of mucins have been described in relation to cancer cell behavior and cell signaling pathways assocd. with epithelial tumorigenesis. Because of the frequent alteration of the pattern of mucin expression in cancers as well as their structural and functional characteristics, mucins are thought to also be involved in response to therapies. In this report, we review the roles of mucins in chemoresistance and the assocd. underlying mol. mechanisms (phys. barrier, resistance to apoptosis, drug metab., cell stemness, epithelial-mesenchymal transition) and discuss the therapeutic tools/strategies and/or prognosis biomarkers for personalized chemotherapy that could be proposed from these studies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1Oqsr3I&md5=982babca9b26013312bb7755fa077530
    13. 13
      Pillai, K.; Pourgholami, M. H.; Chua, T. C.; Morris, D. L. MUC1 as a Potential Target in Anticancer Therapies. Am. J. Clin. Oncol. 2015, 38, 108– 118,  DOI: 10.1097/COC.0b013e31828f5a07
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      MUC1 as a Potential Target in Anticancer Therapies
      Pillai, Krishna; Pourgholami, Mohammad H.; Chua, Terence C.; Morris, David L.
      American Journal of Clinical Oncology (2015), 38 (1), 108-118CODEN: AJCODI; ISSN:0277-3732. (Lippincott Williams & Wilkins)
      MUC1 is a glycoprotein that is overexpressed in tumor cells. In normal cells it forms a protective layer against microbes and toxic chems., besides providing lubrication on ductal surfaces. Oversecretion of MUC1 provide cancer cells with invasiveness, metastasis, and resistance to death induced by reactive oxygen species. MUC1 is made up of 2 heterodimers, MUC1-N and MUC1-C. MUC1-N is heavily glycosylated at 5 regions of the variable N-tandem repeats. MUC1-C is divisible into extracellular, intracellular, and cytoplasmic domain (MUC1-C/CD). The extracellular domain serves as a docking site for epidermal growth factor receptors and other receptor kinases; the transmembrane domain serves to relay messages from extracellular to MUC1-C/CD. The MUC1-C/CD has 5 phosphorylating sites that on interacting with the SH2 domain of specific proteins can stimulate tumor growth. Therapies targeting MUC1 consists of monoclonal antibodies (MAb), vaccines, or small mols. (aptamers). MAb therapies are mainly aimed at MUC1-N with little success, however, new generation of MAb are being developed for MUC1-C. Vaccines (peptide, carbohydrate, glycopeptide, DNA, and dendritic cell) have been developed that recognizes the aberrant glycosylated region of the variable N-tandem repeats in MUC1-N, whereas new generation vaccines are aimed at the cytoplasmic region of MUC1-C. Aptamers (peptides that resemble DNA, RNA) have been used for blocking the dimerization of CQC region and the 5 phosphorylating region of MUC1-C. In addn., aptamers have been used as cytotoxic drug carriers. However, none of the therapies for MUC1 are currently in clin. application, as they need further refinement and evaluation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhs12ktbk%253D&md5=a446f5365795baab0f3d4b6e53c99d86

The authors particular emphasis is on their role in mammary gland biol. , an organ in which the ErbB family and its ligands are critically involved in development, differentiation and cancer.
